introduction.p: Consider the electrical circuit governed by the differential equation L I'' + RI' + \frac{1}{C} I = E'(t). The function E'(t) can have discontinuities. For example, the voltage in the circuit can be periodically turned on and off. The previous methods that we have used to solve second order linear differential equations may not apply here. However, the Laplace transformLaplace transform, an integral transform, allows us to change a differential equation to an algebraic equation.

As a second example, let us consider a population of fish that is governed by exponential growth,
\frac{dP}{dt} & = kP P(0) & = P_0,
and suppose that we wish to determine the effects of seasonal fishing. In other words, harvesting will not be continuous. For example, we might only allow harvesting during the first half of the year, H(t) = \begin{cases} r & 0 \leq t \leq 1/2, \\ 0 & 1/2 \lt t \lt 1, \\ r & 1 \leq t \leq 3/2, \\ 0 & 3/2 \lt t \lt 2, \\ & \vdots \end{cases} We do not yet have the tools to analyze differential equations possessing discontinuous terms.

Given an initial-value problem
ay'' + by' + cy & = g(t) y(0) & = y_0 y'(0) & = y_0',
the idea is to use the Laplace transform to change the differential equation into an equation that can be solved algebraically and then transform the algebraic solution back into a solution of the differential equation. Surprisingly, this method will even work when g is a discontinuous function, provided the discontinuities are not too bad.

subsection.title: Definition of the Laplace Transform
subsection.p: We shall define the Laplace transformLaplace transformdefinition of a function f(t) by {\mathcal L}(f)(s)= F(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} f(t) \, dt, provided the integral converges.

example.p:
The Laplace transform has many nice properties, especially with respect to the derivative of f. However, before we investigate these properties, let us compute several Laplace transforms.
Let f(t) = k, where k is a constant. Then {\mathcal L}(f)(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st}k \; dt = \frac{k}{s}, for s \gt 0.
For f(t) = t, the Laplace transform is {\mathcal L}(f)(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} t \, dt = \frac{1}{s^2}, for s \gt 0.
If f(t) = e^{at} with t > 0, then {\mathcal L}(f)(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} e^{at} \, dt = \int_0^\infty e^{-(s -a)t} \, dt = \left[ - \frac{e^{-(s -a)t}}{s - a} \right]_0^\infty. Noting that e^{-(s -a)t} \to 0 as t \to \infty for s \gt a, we find that {\mathcal L}(e^{at}) = \frac{1}{s - a} \quad \text{for} \quad s \gt a

The Laplace transform of a function does not always exist, even for functions that are infinitely differentiable. For example, let f(t) = e^{t^2}. Then for any real number s, \int_0^b e^{t^2} e^{-st} \, dt = \int_0^b e^{t(t-s)} \, dt, and the integrand is greater then one for t \gt s. Thus, the integral \int_0^\infty e^{t^2} e^{-st} \, dt does not converge.

subsection.p: The Laplace transform, however, does exist in many cases. We will show that the Laplace transform of a function exists if the function does not grow too quickly and has no bad discontinuities.

subsection.title: Properties of the Laplace Transform
subsection.p:
One of the most important properties of the Laplace transform is linearity. That is, {\mathcal L} ( \alpha f + \beta g )(s) = \alpha {\mathcal L}(f)(s) + \beta {\mathcal L} ( g)(s), where \alpha, \beta \in {\mathbb R} provided the Laplace transforms of f and g exist. The proof of this statement follows directly from the definition of the Laplace transform and the properties of integration,
{\mathcal L} ( \alpha f + \beta g )(s) \amp = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} [\alpha f(t) + \beta g(t)] \, dt \amp = \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_0^b e^{-st} [\alpha f(t) + \beta g(t)] \, dt \amp = \alpha \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_0^b e^{-st} f(t) \, dt + \beta \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_0^b e^{-st}\beta g(t) \, dt \amp = \alpha {\mathcal L}(f)(s) + \beta {\mathcal L} ( g)(s)
Transforms of functions having the linearity property are called linear operatorslinear operator.

example.p: Recall that \sinh at = (e^{at} - e^{-at})/2. Provided a \gt 0, linearity makes it very easy to compute the Laplace transform of \sinh at. By , {\mathcal L} ( \sinh at) = \frac{1}{2} {\mathcal L} ( e^{at}) - \frac{1}{2} {\mathcal L} ( e^{-at}) = \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{1}{s - k} - \frac{1}{s + k} \right). Thus, for s \gt k \gt 0, {\mathcal L} ( \sinh at) = \frac{k}{s^2 - k^2}.

subsection.p:
The Laplace transform of discontinuous functions also exist, provided the disconinuities are not too bad. We say that a function f is piecewise continuous on an interval [a, b] if f satisfies the following conditions.
There are a finite number of discontinuities of f on [a, b].
If c \in [a, b] is a discontinuity, then the one-sided limits \lim_{t \to c^-} f(t) \qquad \mbox{and} \qquad \lim_{t \to c^+} f(t) both exist. We also assume that \lim_{t \to a^+} f(t) and \lim_{t \to b^-} f(t) exist.
We say that a function is piecewise continuouspiecewise continuous on an interval [0, \infty) if it is piecewise continuous on the interval [0, b] for all b \gt 0. The types of discontinuities that we are describing are sometimes called jump discontinuitiesjump discontinuities. If a function is piecewise continuous, then the continuities are not too bad.

example.p: One of the simplest piecewise continuous functions is u(t) = \begin{cases} 0, & t \lt 0 \\ 1, & t \geq 0. \end{cases} The function u(t) has a jump discontinuity at t = 0. It follows very quickly that {\mathcal L}(u(t)) = 1/s for s \gt 0.

If we define the unit step function at a to be u_a(t) = u(t - a) = \begin{cases} 0, & t \lt a \\ 1, & t \geq a, \end{cases} then we have a jump discontinuity at t = a. If a \gt 0, then {\mathcal L}(u_a(t)) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} u_a(t) \, dt = \int_a^\infty e^{-st} \, dt = \lim_{b \to \infty} \left[ -\frac{e^{-st}}{s} \right]_a^b = \frac{e^{-sa}}{s}, where s \gt 0 and a \gt 0.

subsection.title: Existence and Uniqueness of the Laplace Transform
subsection.p: If we are to use Laplace transforms to study differential equations, we would like to know which functions actually have Laplace transforms. Furthermore, if two functions have the same Laplace transform, we can ask if the functions must be the same. In other words, we wish to know if the Laplace transform of a function exists and is unique. We can answer both of these questions affirmatively if the function f(t) defined on [0, \infty) does not grow too quickly as t \to \infty. We say a function f(t) is exponentially boundedfunctionexponentially bounded on [0, \infty) if there exist constants M \geq 0 and a such that |f(t)| \leq Me^{at}, for all t in [0, \infty). In other words, the graph of f must lie between the curves y = Me^{at} and y = -Me^{at}. The following two theorems tell us that Laplace transforms exist and are unique for piecewise continuous, exponentially bounded functions on the interval [0, \infty). We leave the proofs of these theorem as exercises.

statement.p: If f is a piecewise continuous, exponentially bounded function defined [0, \infty), then the Laplace transform of f, {\mathcal L}(f)(s)= F(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} f(t) \, dt exists.

Let f and g be two piecewise continuous exponentially bounded functions with Laplace transforms, F(s) and G(s), respectively. Suppose that F(s) = G(s) for all s \gt c, where c is some positive number. Then f(t) = g(t) for all t \geq 0.

subsection.p: In light of , it now makes sense to define the inverse Laplace transformLaplace transforminverse Laplace transform of a function F(s), which we will denote by {\mathcal L}^{-1}(F(s))(t), as the function f(t) whose unique Laplace transform is F(s). Furthermore, the inverse Laplace transform is linear, {\mathcal L}^{-1} ( \alpha F + \beta G ) = \alpha {\mathcal L}^{-1}(F) + \beta {\mathcal L}^{-1} ( G).

We can now solve our initial value problem. Since the Laplace transform of e^{at} is 1/(s - a), we know that {\mathcal L}^{-1} \left( \frac{1}{s-a}\right) = e^{at}, and the solution that we seek is y(t) = \frac{3}{5} e^{3t} + \frac{7}{5} e^{-2t}. Of course, there are much easier methods that we can use if we would like to solve this particular initial value problem, but it is nice to see that the two methods agree.

subsection.title: Finding Laplace Transforms and Inverse Transforms
subsection.p: To use the method of Laplace transforms effectively, we need either tables or computer software such as Sage so that we can easily find Laplace transforms and inverse Laplace transforms.

Let y = y(t) be a piecewise continuous, exponentially bounded function and assume that y' is also exponentially bounded. Then for large values of s {\mathcal L}(y')(s) = s {\mathcal L}(y)(s) - y(0) = s Y(s) - y(0), where Y(s) is the Laplace transform of y.

Let y = y(t) and y'(t) be piecewise continuous, exponentially bounded functions and assume that y'' is exponentially bounded. Then for large values of s {\mathcal L}(y'')(s) = s^2 {\mathcal L}(y)(s) - sy(0) - y'(0)= s^2 Y(s) - sy(0) - y'(0), where Y(s) is the Laplace transform of y. In general, if y = y(t) and all of its derivatives up to order k - 1 are piecewise continuous, exponentially bounded functions and y^{(k)} is piecewise continuous, then
{\mathcal L}(y^{(k)})(s) = s^k {\mathcal L}(y)(s) - s^{k - 1}y(0) - \cdots - s y^{(k -2)}(0) - y^{(k -1)}(0) = s^k Y(s) - s^{k - 1}y(0) - s^{k - 1}y(0)- \cdots - s y^{(k -2)}(0) - y^{(k -1)}(0).
